article.title: Experimentally bounding deviations from quantum theory in the landscape of generalized probabilistic theories

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following GPTs depicted in Figure 1 **does not** satisfy the no-restriction hypothesis?
choices: A qubit
A classical bit
The k=4 system in Boxworld
The convex closure of the Spekkens toy theory for the simplest system (k=4)

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the solid blue shape in Figure 1(a)(i) represent?
choices: The true effect space for a qubit
The dual of the qubit effect space
The true state space for a qubit
The space of logically possible qubit states

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1(e), what dimensionality do the state and effect spaces have for the generic GPT obtained from a randomly generated rank-4 matrix of probabilities?
Which space must always contain the true state space (S) in a GPT?
choices: Srealized
Slogical
Sconsistent
Econsistent

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the space Econsistent represent?
choices: All effects that return probabilities between 0 and 1 when applied to every state in S.
All effects which return probabilities between 0 and 1 when applied to every state in Srealized.
The set of measurement effects actually realized in the experiment.
The dual of the true effect space E.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the figure, what is the relationship between Elogical and E?
choices: Elogical is always equal to E.
Elogical is always strictly contained within E.
Elogical always contains E.
There is no fixed relationship between Elogical and E.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the matrix F represent?
choices: The true probability matrix.
The matrix of experimental finite-run relative frequencies.
The best-fit rank-k matrix.
The matrix of realized GPT state vectors.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the statistical analysis performed on the candidate model set?
choices: To determine the best-fit probability matrix Drealized.
To estimate the dimension k of the data.
To find a decomposition D˜realized = S˜realizedE˜realized.
To visualize the realized GPT state and effect spaces.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the final output of the self-consistent GPT tomography procedure?
choices: The true GPT state and effect spaces.
The best-fit probability matrix Drealized.
The estimated spaces of states and effects realized in the experiment (S˜realized and E˜realized).
The dimension k of the data.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model rank consistently demonstrates poor fit to both datasets (first and second experiment) based on the χ² goodness-of-fit test?
Which model rank is identified as the most likely to describe the data in both experiments based on the AIC score?
What does the relative model likelihood in Figure 6(c) and 6(f) indicate?
choices: The statistical variance in the fitted χ² value.
The likelihood that a model of a given rank best describes the data compared to other models.
The number of parameters required to specify a matrix of a given rank.
The volume ratio between S˜realized and S˜consistent.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the gap between the solid blue polytope (S˜realized) and the wireframe polytope (S˜consistent) in Figure 7(a) and 7(d) represent?
choices: The uncertainty in the estimated space of logically possible GPT states.
The amount of noise in the preparations and measurements.
The discrepancy between the realized GPT state space and the true GPT state space.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: How is the realized GPT effect space, E˜realized, visualized in Figure 7?
choices: As a 3-dimensional solid green polytope.
As a 4-dimensional solid green shape.
As a pair of 3-dimensional projections of the 4-dimensional solid green shape.
As a wireframe polytope surrounding the realized GPT state space.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which experiment (first or second) does a better job at narrowing down the possibilities for the true state space?
choices: The first experiment.
The second experiment.
Both experiments perform equally well.
The figure does not provide sufficient information to answer this question.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula expresses the key concept of factorizing the probability matrix D in the context of GPTs. What do the matrices S and E represent?\n\n**Formula (1): D = SE**
choices: S represents the space of all possible states, and E represents the space of all possible effects.
S represents a matrix of state vectors associated with each preparation, and E represents a matrix of effect vectors associated with each effect.
S represents the set of tomographically complete measurements, and E represents the set of tomographically complete preparations.
S represents the logically possible states, and E represents the logically possible effects.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula describes the fundamental assumption of an ontological model reproducing the predictions of an operational theory. What does the term p(λ|P) represent?\n\n**Formula (4): p(O|M,P) = Σλ∈Λ p(O|λ,M)p(λ|P)**
choices: The probability of obtaining outcome O given the ontic state λ and measurement M.
The probability of the system being in ontic state λ given that it was prepared according to preparation procedure P.
The probability of obtaining outcome O given measurement M and preparation P.
The probability of measurement M being performed given preparation P.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula specifies a critical value related to a specific noncontextuality inequality. What does CNC represent?\n\n**Formula (10): CNC = 3/4**
choices: The maximum value of the probability of success in parity-oblivious multiplexing achievable in quantum theory.
The maximum value of the probability of success in parity-oblivious multiplexing achievable in any operational theory admitting of a universally noncontextual ontological model.
The amount by which the probability of success in parity-oblivious multiplexing can exceed the classical bound in quantum theory.
The minimum value of the probability of success in parity-oblivious multiplexing achievable in any operational theory.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula defines a critical value for a well-known Bell inequality. What does Bloc represent?\n\n**Formula (26): Bloc = 3/4**
choices: The maximum value of the Bell quantity achievable in quantum theory.
The minimum value of the Bell quantity achievable in any operational theory.
The maximum value of the Bell quantity achievable in a model satisfying local causality and the other assumptions of Bell\'s theorem.
The amount by which the Bell quantity can exceed the classical bound in quantum theory.
